awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: RUI: Effects of N and P deposition on stoichiometry, structure, and function of whole-aquatic ecosystems (Bromeliaceae and Sarraceniaceae)
awd_abstract_narration:
Human activity has more than doubled global nitrogen and phosphorus input to the biosphere. Nitrogen loading from fossil fuels and fertilizer is much larger in North America and Europe than in the Southern Hemisphere. Phosphorus loading comes mostly from agriculture. It is smaller in the Northern Hemisphere, but especially important in the tropics. In tropical forests of Central America and Asia, however, nitrogen input is increasing and will continue to do so in coming decades. Changes in the input of these critically important elements are profoundly changing ecosystem structure and function. Ecosystem responses to these changes remain poorly understood. This project will fill this knowledge gap by studying the miniature ecosystems that exist within pitcher plants. These plants are widely distributed across the tropics. They are useful as model environments to study the effects of changes in nitrogen and phosphorus inputs on ecosystem structure and function. This research will use pitcher plants to advance our understanding of ecosystem responses to environmental changes. Results of this work will inform management of ecosystems subject to changing nitrogen and phosphorus loading. It will also train graduate and undergraduate students, and will engage large numbers of high school students in the scientific process. 

This study will quantify elemental patterns by conducting standardized field surveys of phytotelmata ecosystems across large geographical gradients of nitrogen (N) and phosphorus (P) deposition. Leaves of tank bromeliads and pitcher plants form compartments that fill with rainwater. These compartments capture leaf litter and arthropod prey, which provide the energy to support a persistent food web of invertebrates. These systems provide an opportunity to test for nutrient deposition effects on the standing stocks and fluxes of nutrients for the whole ecosystem and within different ecosystem sub-modules (e.g., bromeliad and pitcher tissue, periphyton, water, and macroinvertebrates). This study will reveal whether whole-ecosystem stoichiometry reflects local availability of N and P, or whether stoichiometric ratios are buffered across deposition gradients. Overall, the well-defined aquatic habitats created by phytotelmata and their broad geographic distribution allow the researchers to examine large-scale patterns of diversity, stoichiometry, and ecosystem function in a relatively invariant habitat. This research will give insight into the geography of N and P within and across replicated whole ecosystems. It will also test the ecosystem-level consequences of increased nutrient inputs at scales difficult or impossible to achieve in more traditional aquatic habitats.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Overview: 

The goal of the NSF project “Collaborative Research: RUI: Effects of N and P deposition on stoichiometry, structure, and function of whole-aquatic ecosystems (Bromeliaceae and Sarraceniaceae)” was to understand how nitrogen and phosphorus deposition affect the structure, stoichiometry, and functioning of aquatic ecosystems contained in natural microcosms of phytotelmata plants Bromeliaceae and Sarraceniaceae. We tested elemental responses of algae, microbes, and macroinvertebrates to nutrient enrichment by conducting standardized field surveys of these ecosystems across large geographical gradients of nitrogen (N) and phosphorus (P) deposition in North America and South America. Bromeliads and pitcher plants provide an opportunity to test for nutrient deposition effects on the standing stocks and fluxes of nutrients for the whole ecosystem and within different ecosystem sub-modules (e.g., bromeliad and pitcher tissue, periphyton, water, and macroinvertebrates). This project set up an unprecedented sampling of these ecosystems for bromeliads across Brazil (10 sites) and pitcher plants from South Florida to the Canadian border (28 sites). At each site, we characterized the structure of the aquatic communities (species richness, species abundance, biomass) and elemental composition (carbon, nitrogen, and phosphorus) of macro and microorganisms.

 

Intellectual Merit:

This project integrated elements from community and ecosystem ecology to help advance our understanding of the consequences of major changes in biogeochemical cycles on aquatic ecosystems. A key challenge for understanding ecosystem-level effects of global change are the responses of whole-ecosystems. Most studies to date have focused on ecosystem sub-compartments because of the intractability of most ecosystems to be studied as a whole entity. However, phytotelmata provides spatially discrete and highly-replicated ecosystems, facilitating surveys and manipulations of all components of the macro-invertebrate food web and its basal resources. Our work advanced understanding of large-scale spatial variation in the stoichiometry of multiple taxonomic groups and given insight into the ecosystem-level consequences of increased nutrient inputs in the tropics and temperate regions. We have published five scientific papers to date, and three more are in progress. We also presented our results in 15 invited seminars and seven conferences, the latter mainly presented by students working in the project. We learned about the distinct degree of stability (stoichiometric plasticity and species turnover) of different taxonomic and functional groups to changes in biogeochemical cycles. This project also allowed us to perform data synthesis studies on the consequences of nutrient enrichment for invertebrates in aquatic and terrestrial systems, evidencing the potentially strong negative effects of nutrient enrichment on the population abundances of invertebrates. The results from this research are applicable to other natural aquatic microcosms, including other aquatic phytotelmata systems, tree holes, and rock pools, but also the mechanisms we identified may be useful for understanding the responses of larger natural systems like ponds or lakes to nutrient deposition.

 

Broader Impacts:

Nutrient enrichment and eutrophication of aquatic ecosystems are pressing global problems, the findings of our research are informing management strategies, especially in the tropics (e.g., Brazilian Institute of Environment and Renewable Natural Resources, which have not yet experienced widespread N deposition. This project has led to research opportunities and training of five graduate students (four US and one Brazilian) and >10 undergraduate US and Brazilian students. These students were trained in US institutions (Rutgers University and the University of Vermont) and Brazlian Universities (UNICAMP and UFRJ), in aquatic ecology, ecological stoichiometry, gerographical sampling, community ecology analyses, and elemental analyses. Most of these students were women and people of color, which are underrepresented in science. Further, at least three additional MSc students are working with data collected during this project and working toward their degrees (estimated graduation May 2025). The project also contributed to create new collaboration networks among US and Brazilian collaborators.
